messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Chappell, Simon P [mailto:simon.chappell@...]
> Sent: Thursday, November 20, 2003 11:26 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Testing philosophy question
>
> I had not previously realised that this was a hotly debated
> subject, but I can think of at least one example of a test
> that should have at least two assertion in it: the equals() method.

I'm not necessarily disagreeing with you but I think it is always
possible to re-write the test so it only has one assertion in it. For
example:

public class TestSomeObectEquals extends TestCase
{
private SomeObject m_a = null;
private SomeObject m_b = null;

public void setUp()
{
m_a = new SomeObject("abc");
m_b = new someObject("abc");
}

public void testSymmetryAB()
{
assertTrue("Symmetry test a == b failed.", m_a.equals(m_b));
}

public void testSymmetryBA()
{
assertTrue("Symmetry test b == a failed.", m_b.equals(m_a));
}
}

I think better names could be used but you get the idea.... As long as
your tests stay focused and are easy to understand I don't think it
really matters how many assertions the test contains. For example:
public void testSymmetry()
{
assertTrue("Symmetry test a == b failed.", m_a.equals(m_b));
assertTrue("Symmetry test b == a failed.", m_b.equals(m_a));
}
Is just as easy to read as when each assertion was in its own method in
my opinion.


> Also, what about edge-conditions?

Each edge condition could be in its own test method.

Kris
